title: 103_hr4959
content:
The "Maritime Regulatory Reform Act of 1994" is cited as the short title. It introduces safety management and alternative compliance measures in Chapter 21 of title 46, United States Code. The Secretary may prescribe regulations governing the merchant marine of the United States, personnel, and shore-based management to implement the International Management Code for the Safe Operation of Ships and Pollution Prevention. Compliance with these regulations is voluntary until mandatory compliance dates provided for in the International Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea. The Secretary may establish optional regulatory requirements for compliance programs, with a focus on quality control and safety. Vessel owners and operators may be required to maintain records and submit reports as deemed necessary. SEC. 3. USE OF REPORTS, DOCUMENTS, AND CERTIFICATES.

The Secretary may utilize reports, documents, and certificates from reliable sources for marine safety, security, and environmental protection.

SEC. 4. EQUIPMENT APPROVAL. Section 3306(b) of title 46, United States Code, is amended to require prior approval for the use of regulated equipment on vessels. The Secretary may accept approvals from foreign governments that meet international safety standards, but must consider the need to maintain high safety levels. SEC. 5. FREQUENCY OF INSPECTION amended to include small passenger vessels carrying more than 12 passengers on international voyages. Inspection interval changed from 2 years to 5 years for certain vessels. SEC. 6. CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION. SEC. 6. CERTIFICATE OF INSPECTION amended to remove time limit for inspection interval. SEC. 7. CLASSIFICATION SOCIETIES. Section 3316 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to rely on reports from recognized classification societies for vessel inspections. The Secretary may delegate inspection duties to these societies or their agents. The Secretary can rely on recognized classification societies for vessel inspections and may delegate inspection duties to them or their agents. The Bureau or society may issue required certificates for vessel documentation. The Secretary can delegate vessel inspection duties to recognized classification societies, who may issue required certificates for vessel documentation. "Sec. 3316. Classification societies."
